dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: ...blown a hole in the reserves of these major international oil companies, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...blown a hole in the reserves of these major international oil companies, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Years of under-investment in exploration and a decline in project development has blown a hole in the reserves of the major international oil companies (IOCs), a group that includes ExxonMobil, Chevron and Royal Dutch Shell.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, like, since 2015, Host_A, it's just wild, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, like, since twenty fifteen, Host_A, it's just wild, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2015 the average reserves of the oil majors has fallen by 25% to now stand at less than 10 years of annual production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2015 the average reserves of the oil majors has fallen by 25% to now stand at less than 10 years of annual production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And now it's, uh, it's less than ten years of production!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And now it's, uh, it's less than ten years of production!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2015 the average reserves of the oil majors has fallen by 25% to now stand at less than 10 years of annual production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, nine point five years average. It's, um, it's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, nine point five years average. It's, um, it's insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IOC average of 9.5 years is now 25% below where the industry was prior to the oil price collapse in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And investors are seeing this, right? It's a huge negative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And investors are seeing this, right? It's a huge negative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reserves in the ground is a critical measure of an oil company with a decline seen as a negative by investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Citi's calling it a 'looming challenge' in their report.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Citi's calling it a 'looming challenge' in their report.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citi, an investment bank, noted the industry-wide decline of reserves in a research note published last week under the headline: Falling IOC Reserves A Looming Challenge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A looming challenge, yes. And it's not just, like, an inconvenience for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A looming challenge, yes. And it's not just, like, an inconvenience for them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's, um, it's an existential threat! For some of these giants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's, um, it's an existential threat! For some of these giants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The worst interpretation of falling reserves is that it might be an existential threat to the long-term survival of an oil company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: An existential threat! That's the worst interpretation. Wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: An existential threat! That's the worst interpretation. Wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The worst interpretation of falling reserves is that it might be an existential threat to the long-term survival of an oil company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And it's all because of, like, under-investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And it's all because of, like, under-investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Years of under-investment in exploration and a decline in project development has blown a hole in the reserves of the major international oil companies (IOCs)...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Under-investment, uh, and regulatory scrutiny, too, right? Especially in Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Under-investment, uh, and regulatory scrutiny, too, right? Especially in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. But here's the thing, the cash flow from oil? That's what's paying for green initiatives!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. But here's the thing, the cash flow from oil? That's what's paying for green initiatives!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Arguments that reserves are less relevant in an industry facing a transition away from oil and gas misses the point that it is cash flow from oil which is paying for investment in new energy sources such as wind and solar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Black pays for green! That quote! I saw that, like, eighty percent of their cash flow still comes from oil and gas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Black pays for green! That quote! I saw that, like, eighty percent of their cash flow still comes from oil and gas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the recent words of one IOC chief executive black pays for green a reference to the 80% of CFFO (cash flow from operations) that is generated from oil and gas activities...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes! And they project, what, seventy percent by 2030? So, those reserves are critical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! And they project, what, seventy percent by twenty thirty? So, those reserves are critical.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and likely to still be more than 70% by 2030, Citi said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So critical! And you see these two clear groups forming, like, ten and a half years versus, what, eight years?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So critical! And you see these two clear groups forming, like, ten and a half years versus, what, eight years?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citi said there were two clear groups forming across the oil sector with six IOCs tightly grouped around reserve life of around 10.5 years. ... There are three IOCs in another group (Repsol, Equinor and Shell) which have reserves around eight years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Eight years! Can you believe it? Shell's in that group. It's, uh, it's a ticking clock.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eight years! Can you believe it? Shell's in that group. It's, uh, it's a ticking clock.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are three IOCs in another group (Repsol, Equinor and Shell) which have reserves around eight years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A ticking clock, exactly! The energy transition is really, really hitting them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A ticking clock, exactly! The energy transition is really, really hitting them.
